the very easy and obvious solution is to make the stats additive and introduce diminishing returns for very large divisions to reflect the fact it's harder to *organize* larger divisions.

can you give me a youtube link or something where I can see an example of tanks being insurmountable for pure infantry to deal with? because so far I can't find anything and investing in tanks to try it out has yet to show me the strength of tanks. Usually (as I said) whenever I try to use tank divisions I fail because I either spent too much army xp on the tank division so my inf suffers and dies or I spend on inf divisions and the tanks are just not needed and any production invested on them is a waste

can you explain your point about combat width because I'm not sure I get what you mean.
You are right that their meager attack is a big problem. In reality their main purpose is to negate or overcome enemy entrenchment, this could be modeled in game by removing enemy entrenchment bonuses to defense if your tanks are not being pierced for example. If they also boosted up entrenchment to the point where infart could not break each other (defense always winning 4:1 or more) they would replicate the real-life conditions that brought about the need for tanks in the first place.
The biggest thing I don't understand about tanks is why they have such low org, why a pure tank division can't just steam roll an infantry division with zero anti-tank support or line divisions is complete bs.

I've never seen significantly better results from adding tanks to my configuration though, in fact often I feel like I'm less powerful by diluting my production compared to just sticking to infart. Do you have an example of a playthrough where you can make significant use of tanks (not Germany USA or soviets)?
I've always thought tanks were meant to allow you to leverage production output to overcome manpower shortage but it seems to me no country with manpower shortage is able to produce tanks and have an effective army simultaneously
